69316.description:
IRONDIE uses combinations of nine different types of dice, each available in eight different colors, which allows for endless possibilities in terms of personalized sets so that you can surprise your friends with new tactics and combinations. IRONDIE dice are beautifully crafted and can also be used with existing board games, roleplaying games, or miniatures wargames.

IRONDIE dice are made of silver-plated Zamac (an alloy with a base metal of zinc and alloying elements of aluminium, magnesium and copper; the first limited edtion was made of white metal) and covered with a colored translucent paint to highlight their metal luster. Their mass is much more substantial than any plastic or resin die resulting in a better gaming feel and experience.

IRONDIE is not a difficult game, but the difference between playing and mastering it lies in the player's experience. A champion will have well-composed sets of dice and know how best to make use of them.
69316.name: IRONDIE

69318.description:
They said it couldn't be done.

They were right.

Nonetheless, you've been enlisted to help inventor extraordinaire Ted Alspach put the finishing touches on his Perpetual-Motion Machine. Your job is to make the machine as efficient as possible, so that you might fool the unsuspecting public long enough to make Mr. Alspach incredibly rich before he's chased out of town by a crazed mob of very cranky investors.

You're pitted against one to three other players who are also looking to get as famous as possible by riding Mr. Alspach's coattails. You'll need cunning, foresight and a bit of luck in order to beat your opponents.

Perpetual-Motion Machine is a game of set collection, skill-tree building, and long and short term strategy. Race against other players to build the most efficient machine possible using limited resources. As you build, you'll choose which areas to focus on to ensure victory.

Reimplemented by


Kniffel: Das Kartenspiel
69318.name: Perpetual-Motion Machine

69319.name: Tras el Unicornio: Searching the Unicorn
69319.description:
According to a legend in 1471 by order of Henry IV King of Castille, called the Impotent, set out one expedition to Africa, beyond the land of the Moors.
The secret aim of this expedition was to hunt a unicorn, since it was assumed that the horn of this mythological creature could increase the virility of the king.
In 1946 the results of the exhumation of the corpse of Henry IV alongside the king's mummified remains found a gray spindle object, which was proved to be a fragment of African rhino horn.

So begins and ends the novel "In Search of the Unicorn" by Juan Eslava Galan awarderd Planeta Prize in 1987, being the original idea for this game. Each player leads an expedition sent to hunt the unicorn, but in the way they could get other valuable things like gold, trading on the Silk Road and to evangelize people in the name of his master Henry IV of Castille. All this if the expeditioners survived the attacks of nomade tribes with whom they have to fight. Many dangers and soldiers will die during the way and what is worse, maybe you the leader will also fall before reaching your goal ... who will get the horn and gets the grace of the king?

---

En 1471 por orden de Enrique IV de Castilla, llamado el Impotente, parte una expedición desde Segovia con destino los pastizales de Africa, más allá de la tierra de los moros.
El objetivo secreto de esta expedición era cazar un unicornio, ya que se suponía que su cuerno podía aumentar la virilidad del rey.
Según reza el Acta de la Exhumación del cadáver de Enrique IV de 1946, junto a los restos momificados del rey se encontró un objeto fusiforme gris, que una vez identificado por el C.S.I.C. resultó ser un fragmento de cuerno de rinoceronte africano.

Así comienza y termina la novela “En busca del unicornio” de Juan Eslava Galán que fue Premio Planeta en 1987, y que sirve como idea para este juego. Cada jugador dirige una expedición para cazar el unicornio, pero por el camino podrá conseguir oro, comerciar en la ruta de la seda y hasta evangelizar pueblos para ensalzar la figura de su señor Enrique IV de Castilla. Todo esto si sobrevive a los ataques de los pueblos nómadas con los que tendrá que luchar. A lo largo de la expedición es posible que tus compañeros pierdan la vida y lo que es peor, a lo mejor tu también caes…¿serás tu quien gane el favor del rey?

69322.name: Mad Bishops
69322.description:
Mad Bishops is a two-player game which uses a 10x10 checkerboard, 25 red checkers and 25 blue checkers. The board is initially set up as shown in the figure.

The checkers function like Chess bishops with two restrictions. On your turn you must either kill, or move into position to kill. If a checker is already in position to kill, it can only be used to kill. Killing is not mandatory. I.e. if you can move an unengaged checker to engage the enemy, you can do that instead.

Mad Bishops is a game of annihilation. I.e., you must kill all enemy checkers to win.

69323.name: Bid$
69323.description:
From the box:

"Bid$ is a truly challenging experience that is totally unique from most board games in that any property is available, if you are willing to bid the right price. You can taste the satisfaction of forcing your opponents to pay too much for their modest properties, or jump at the opportunity of stealing a legitimate good deal by being shrewd and cunning. If you like fast paced competitive fun that keeps the chance factor to a minimum, try Bid$, the game where you do control your own destiny."

Object of the game (2-6 players) - To make as much money as possible by buying stores and eventually towers. Each player picks a marker and starts at "receive $1500" (you do not collect the money until you have gone around the board once). All players play around the outside edge (lower level) and can only move into the upper level (inside edge) with a bank payment of $15,000. The players begin by rolling the dice, and the player with with the highest number starts first. The rest of the order is determined by going clockwise. When play begins, if a player rolls doubles, he/she is allowed to go again. The player keeps rolling until he/she stops getting doubles (property that you hit along the way must be bid on or if it is owned the owner must be paid). Each player is given $21,000 at the start of the game. When a property is landed on, the bidding starts.

69324.name: Colonnade
69324.description:
Colonnade is a two person game which uses a 1x8 board, 12 red checkers and 12 blue checkers. The board is initially set up as shown in the figure.

You can pick up any one of your checkers from a stack, carrying the checkers above it along, and place it onto an adjacent stack that’s topped with a checker of your color. (A stack can be of height 1.) Complete such a move with a discard. I.e. if two like-colored checkers are adjacent in a stack, discard one of the two checkers.

You can also move a checker down to an unoccupied square. You can't slide a bottom checker sideways to an unoccupied square.

The last player to have a move available wins. I.e. if you don't have a move available on your turn, you lose.

69325.name: X-COM: UFO Defense
69325.description:
User summary:
A tactical, turn-based strategy game designed by Julian Gollop that expands upon his earlier game Laser Squad. The goal of the game is to stop alien invasion of the Earth. This is accomplished by shooting down alien vessels, defeating or capturing the surviving aliens, researching new technologies to improve available weapons and vehicles, and eventually attacking the enemy bases.


Reimplemented by the original developers, Julian and Nick Gollop as Laser Squad Nemesis


Inspired on the movie "Invasion: UFO"

69326.name: Wanderlust
69326.description:
In Wanderlust, you are racing through an arrow maze, trying to pick up the right Things and take those Things where you can win with them.

The playing area consists of a 6x7 grid of double-sided tiles. On one face, the tiles display the possible moves and on the other, places for winning and actions available to the players. After having done the action or move shown on a tile, the player flips the tile over.

Like Fluxx, the Goals are indefinite, but unlike Fluxx, Wanderlust requires much more turn-by-turn planning.

Complete rules, example turns, and PDFs are available at:
http://ceruleansgames.tripod.com/wanderlust.htm

videogameversion: North American Game Boy Advance edition
North American NES Classic Series (Gray Cartridge) edition
videogamecompilation: The Legend of Zelda:  Collector's Edition
videogame: The Legend of Zelda:  Collector's Edition
69327.description:
From the back of the "Classic NES Series" box:

The Legend of ZELDA


Link's legendary first quest unfolds in the Classic NES adventure for the Game Boy Advance!

The Legend of Zelda invented a genre and captivated a gaming generation. Now you can play the timeless NES adventure on your Game Boy Advance! The evil warlock Ganon has imprisoned the Princess Zelda and plunged the peaceful land of Hyrule into darkness and despair. Only a young boy named Link has the courage to answer the call for a hero. Will he find the lost Triforce fragments, slay Ganon, and save Princess Zelda? Only you can decide the fate of Hyrule!

User Summary:
This is the game that introduced Link, Zelda, Hyrule, and Ganon. The adventure begins with Link setting out on a quest to rescue Princess Zelda from the evil clutches of Ganon. Along the way, Link must grow in strength by acquiring more lifeforce (heart), more equipment (tools), some armor, gems (money), and more specialized weapons. The game consists of a top-down view of the map with nearly every screen offering exits on all four sides of the screen. You explore the map through forests, mountains, graveyards, and other fantasy settings in search of dungeons where Ganon and his minions await. The dungeons are more confined and involve more problem-solving to explore and navigate.

Not only has Ganon captured Princess Zelda, but he has also the Triforce of Power. The Triforce of Wisdom has been broken into 8 pieces, and Link must acquire these before he can challenge Ganon and save Hyrule. Once you completed the epic quest, the game allowed a second play-through with all of the locations and dungeons in a new configuration.

Individual credits:
Koji Kondo: Music
videogamehonor: 2002 Game Critics Best Action/Adventure Game of the Year Nominee
2002 Game Critics Best of Show Nominee
69327.name: The Legend of Zelda
videogamebg: The Legend of Zelda
The Legend of Zelda: The Hyrule Fantasy
Monopoly: The Legend of Zelda

69328.name: Sälles äventyr
69328.description: A children's game that is not actually about the wacky adventures of the eponymous seal mascot, but a way of teaching seamanship and environmental care among other things. Players navigate the archipelago on the game board with their boats and try to land on special tiles where they can gain point tokens. Depending on the colour of the tile, this is done by answering questions, drawing pictures or giving small performances. As an added twist, only some of the point tokens actually represent real points, meaning the scores of the players are hidden until the end of the game.

videogameversion: North American Game Boy Advance edition
North American NES Classic Series (Gray Cartridge) edition
videogamecompilation: The Legend of Zelda:  Collector's Edition
videogame: The Legend of Zelda:  Collector's Edition
69329.description:
"Zelda II: The Adventure of Link is an action role-playing game developed and published by Nintendo for the Nintendo Entertainment System, and it is the second installment in The Legend of Zelda video game series. It was originally released in Japan on the Family Computer Disk System less than a year after the release of the original The Legend of Zelda. Nintendo released Zelda II in Japan on January 14, 1987, seven months before the United States saw the release of the first Zelda title. Nintendo released Zelda II in North America in 1988, two years after its initial release in Japan, converting the game from its initial Disk System format to the NES cartridge.

The Adventure of Link is a direct sequel to the original The Legend of Zelda, again involving the protagonist, Link, on a quest to save Princess Zelda, who has fallen under a sleeping spell. The Adventure of Link's emphasis on side-scrolling and RPG-style elements, however, was a significant departure from its predecessor. The game was highly successful at the time and introduced elements that would become commonplace in future Zelda games. It was followed in 1992 by The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past for the Super NES."

Source: Wikipedia, "Zelda_II:_The_Adventure_of_Link," available under the CC-BY-SA License.
69329.name: Zelda II: The Adventure of Link

69330.name: X-Men Legends II: Rise of Apocalypse
videogamefranchise: Player's Choice (Best Selling Nintendo Games, US & EU)
videogamehonor: 2005 Spike Best RPG of the Year Nominee
69330.description:
"X-Men Legends II: Rise of Apocalypse is a follow up to X-Men Legends. It is an action role-playing game released in 2005 for the Xbox, PlayStation 2, N-Gage, PlayStation Portable, and GameCube video game consoles as well as the PC."

Source: Wikipedia, "X-Men_Legends_II:_Rise_of_Apocalypse," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

69331.name: X-Men Legends
videogamefranchise: Platinum Family Hits (Best Selling Family Xbox Games, US)
Player's Choice (Best Selling Nintendo Games, US & EU)
videogamehonor: 2004 Spike Best RPG of the Year Nominee
2005 D.I.C.E. Best Role-Playing Game of the Year Nominee (Console)
69331.description:
From the game box:

Magneto has unleashed his diabolical plan ever. Now, as Earth falls under a shroud of darkness, X-Men Legends puts the fate of the world in your hands. Combine and customize teams of mutants through an epic series of battles to save mankind.

69332.name: HERO System Martial Arts
69332.description:
Can your kung fu beat your enemy's kung fu? It can if you've got HERO System Martial Arts! A comprehensive guide to martial arts in the HERO System, HSMA is filled with information and rules about every aspect of the martial arts. It's got everything you need to create and play a martial artist character in any campaign, genre, time period, or setting.

Source: Publisher's Blurb

videogamefranchise: Greatest Hits (Best Selling PlayStation Games, US)
Platinum Range (Best Selling PlayStation Games, PAL)
videogamecompilation: Metal Gear Solid: The Essential Collection
videogameversion: North American PlayStation 2 (The Essential collection) edition
69333.description:
"Metal Gear Solid 2: Sons of Liberty (commonly abbreviated as MGS2) is a stealth action video game directed by Hideo Kojima, developed by Konami Computer Entertainment Japan and published by Konami for the PlayStation 2 in 2001. It is the fourth Metal Gear game produced and directed by Kojima and the direct sequel to Metal Gear Solid. Its release was followed by an expanded edition, Metal Gear Solid 2: Substance for PlayStation 2, Xbox and Windows. Metal Gear Solid 3: Snake Eater, a prequel to the entire Metal Gear series, followed in 2004. In 2008, a direct sequel, Metal Gear Solid 4: Guns of the Patriots was released."

Source: Wikipedia, "Metal_Gear_Solid_2:_Sons_of_Liberty," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

videogame: The Legend of Zelda:  Collector's Edition
69334.description:
The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time​ was published by Nintendo in 1998. The game is part of the Legend of Zelda series and focuses on the series main character, Link who must save the land of Hyrule from a great evil.

Another one of Shigeru Miyamoto projects (creator of Mario, Donkey Kong, Star Fox) the game sold over 7 million copies worldwide and placed second in Official Nintendo Magazine's "100 greatest Nintendo games of all time".

Taking place in the land of Hyrule, the game features puzzles, combat, rpg elements as the player controls Link throughout the game. The game allows the player to use objects such as bombs, a bow and arrow, the series trademark Master Sword, and the magical Ocarina of Time. Placing an importance on the music of the game the player will learn a variety of songs throughout the game that Link can play on the Ocarina that will allow him to trigger certain events or teleport Link to the original location where he learned the song. The game also features a simple combat system called "Z-Targeting" allowing the player to target a single enemy at a time and perform advance acrobatic attacks while keeping Link faced on the target.

1998 EGM Platinum Game Winner
1998 Japan Game Awards Best Game of the Year Winner

69334.name: The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time

69335.name: Black Mole (Issue 3 - 1990)
69335.description: Vol. I No. 3 of Black Mole fanzine

69336.name: Heed the Higher Call
69336.description:
From the Introduction:

You hold in your hands a companion to Ascension, a Dark Heresy supplement. Ascension allows you to take your characters into the highest halls of power and influence. This companion is designed to give players and gamemasters more perspective on characters and new options for character creation.

69337.description:
With a strong will like steel Spartans responsed to the call of war:
...
"Go tell the Spartans, stranger passing by,
that here, obedient to their law, we lie."
-Simonides.
...
"During the 2nd Persian Invasion to Greece and after the battles of Thermopylae, Artemision and Boeotia led by Xerxes himself, the Persians retreated after their first loss at the naval Battle of Salamis. Persian forces retreated to Asia and General Mardonius returned to finish what the Persian King has started. He built a fortified camp outside Plataea.

Greeks have assembled an army allied by many cities of ancient Greece. Spartans led the forces of Peloponnesos , Athenians answered the call with many other cities. It was Summer of 479 BC where the two armies has met each other opposed , even if at the Percian forces had many greek traitors and mercenaries, for a battle that actually ended the Persian vanquishment.

General Mardonius met his own destiny in this battle, and General Pausanias from Sparta, has archived a victory , even if their forces were outnumbered."

"Steel Will: 479 BC, The Battle of Plataea" is a history-themed wargame for two players that simulates that battle. With an abstract taste of gameplay, the core of classic historic-wargame and the feeling of a new approach at combat mechanism, we tried to create something that keeps the interest of the players alive!"
69337.name: Steel Will: 479 BC, The Battle of Plataea

69338.name: Fire in the Blood
69338.description:
Publisher Blurb:

Fire in the Blood is the first of five adventures in the Legacy of the First Age series. It contains an exciting and mysterious 4-Act storyline, new creatures and enemies, and five pregenerated characters to get started right away. This scenario can be run either as a stand-alone adventure, or as just the first step on an epic adventure across the Worlds of Sun and Stone.

69339.name: The Imperium Romanum
69339.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This 15 x 21" map depicts the extent of the Roman empire during the time of Cthulhu Invictus. The map is printed in black ink on a natural white stock, folded to be included in the book. When we printed that book, we ended up with some extra Empire maps.

Use this item to avoid defacing or damaging your copy of Cthulhu Invictus. You can then freely scribble and annotate this copy during your gaming sessions.

69340.name: Last Frontier
69340.description:
Publisher blurb:

Adding some pitch black and blood red to the great white north ... fishing villages and fishing village idiots, timber contracts and factory ships, State Troopers in floatplanes and the weird guys who hide when they fly over - set among the emerald forests of southeast Alaska’s vast archipelago, this playset drags an offbeat but familiar setting into the crosshairs.

69341.description:
A box set of three books containing additional rules and scenarios for first edition Warhammer:

Volume 1: Forces of Fantasy
Volume 2: Fighting Fantasy Battles
Volume 3: Arcane Magics

These include extended rules for fleshing out Warhammer armies, more battle rules (particularly for various levels of unit organization), and rules for the use of magic in the game.
69341.name: Warhammer: Forces of Fantasy

69344.name: Solve and Settle
69344.description:
From game designer:

This educational game, meant to help reinforce solving simple Algebraic equations, puts you in the roll of an explorer of a newly discovered land competing against other explorers in an effort to settle the most territories of the land.

The land consists of four different types of territories to settle. The territories are the Plains, the Wetlands, the Forest, and the Mountains.

Each card represents a different territory and contains an equation to be solved. In order to settle a territory one must possess a card containing the solution to the algebraic equation given on any unoccupied territory. Forming empires can lead to overthrowing your opponent’s settlements. But beware, if your opponent can fend off your attack, their settlements become even stronger than before.

The person who settles the most territories rules the land!

69345.description: A supplement for 2nd edition Warhammer that featured full army lists for that edition of the game - the immediate ancestor of the 3rd edition supplement, Warhammer Armies. Included are rules for various armies along with points values, wargear, and full stats for the variety of units included with each.
69345.name: Warhammer: Ravening Hordes

69346.description: A campaign book for the 2001 WFB campaign of the same name - includes rules for fighting in the campaign setting of Albion, including descriptions of the setting, special army lists for running battles, the running of the campaing itself, etc.
69346.name: Warhammer: Dark Shadows

69347.description:
Played on a 10x10 checkered board, each player controls 6 animals of 3 different types. The Mouse can move orthogonally (horizontal or vertical) and is 'scared' of the Lion. The Lion can move diagonally (it's color locked) and is 'scared' of the Elephant. The Elephant can move both orthogonally and diagonally and is 'scared' of the Mouse; each piece can move as far as it can on its intended line of travel as long as it's not within the square perimeter (orthogonal and diagonal) of the animal its afraid of.

The goal of the game is to control 3 of the 4 'watering holes' at the end of your turn. However, if your piece is next to a piece (orthogonal AND diagonal) that it is 'scared' of it MUST move on your next turn. You cannot move a piece next to a piece (orthogonal AND diagonal) that it is 'scared' of.
69347.name: Barca

69348.description: The Warhammer Fantasy Battle equivalent of Warhammer 40,000's Chapter Approved - a short-lived annual (the "Chronicles" name gets on the cover starting with the second annual - the first simply says "Annual"), collecting new and experimental rules from White Dwarf for Warhammer 6th edition. These include rules for combat as well as new or revised army lists or special rules for various armies that didn't make it into the army books of the 6th edition. Like Chapter Approved, each new edition was published in the year prior to the year mentioned in its title.
69348.name: Warhammer Chronicles

69349.name: Junk Mail
69349.description:
Are you tired of all the SPAM emails you get on a daily basis in your inbox? Well here is your chance to spam someone else for a change.

Junk Mail is card game all about spamming other people and trying to protect yourself. You will play spam cards on your opponents and give yourself firewalls, employees and professions for protection and better chances to spam someone else. Maybe you can use a hacker or an advertising rep. to help your cause.

69350.name: Honk!
69350.description:
Do you drive in traffic on a daily basis? How stressful is it dealing with all those crazy drivers every morning and night? Welcome to HONK! the board game all about driving through traffic.
The object of the game is to navigate your car down the freeway and be the first to make it home. That would be simple, but everyone else is trying to do the same thing. Each player has a handful of cards and a number of actions. A player may use cards to gain special movements, inhibit the movement of other players, or move cars out of way. The other thing players can do is strategically move their car. Either way, making it down the freeway is a hoot with flat tires, stalled cars, accidents, and of course the police. Keep your eyes open as this one will be for sale soon!

69351.description: An optional rules supplement for Warhammer 6th edition with a focus on campaigns. Included are rules for running several different kinds of campaigns (including map-based and decision trees), plus rules for special locations and environments and a number of scenarios to run during campaigns.
69351.name: Warhammer: The General's Compendium

69352.name: Satzglieder
69352.description: Learning game which can teach children to recognize sentence constituents. These are printed on little cards and can be combined in different ways. The goal is to form sentences to match the picture tiles included in the game.

69353.name: Dark Cloud 2
videogamefranchise: The Best (Best Selling PlayStation Games, JP)
videogamehonor: 2004 D.I.C.E. Role-Playing Game of the Year Nominee (Console)
2005 British Academy Game Awards Best Adventure Game of the Year Nominee
69353.description:
"The core gameplay of Dark Chronicle is an action RPG with some elements from dungeon crawl games. The player proceeds through a series of randomly created dungeon rooms, which are periodically interrupted by set rooms where they either witness a cutscene or fight a boss. In the dungeons the player will find various materials to use in item construction and Geostones, which are necessary for the Georama.

Outside of dungeons the main focus is the Georama system, where the player is tasked with rebuilding certain locations in order to restore the future. By retrieving Geostones from the dungeons the player is given guidelines for the town as well as plans to make objects (such as houses, bridges and shops) required for filling said guidelines. Along with rebuilding the infrastructure, the town must be populated with inhabitants
"

Source: Wikipedia, "Dark_Chronicle," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

69354.name: Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney
videogamecompilation: Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy HD
69354.description:
"Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney stars Phoenix Wright, a rookie defense attorney in the Fey and Co. Law Offices, owned by fellow defense attorney Mia Fey. The game features five court cases divided into episodes. Each case flips between two game modes: investigation and the actual trial. In the investigation aspect of the game, Phoenix gathers evidence and speaks to characters involved in the case. In the trial aspect of the game, Phoenix defends his client using said evidence, cross examines witnesses and solves the mystery surrounding each case. The court perspective is usually in the third person, while the perspective outside of court is in the first person."

Source: Wikipedia, "Phoenix_Wright:_Ace_Attorney," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

69355.name: Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney: Justice For All
videogamecompilation: Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy HD
69355.description:
User description:

The second game in the Ace Attorney series. Originally released in Japan only for the Gameboy Advance platform, and later re-released for Nintendo DS in Japan, Europe, and US. In 2010 the game was ported to WiiWare.

The plot of this game is a continuation of Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney and features characters from the first game in the series. Justice For All features four new cases for the player to solve.

The gameplay is very similar to the first game, with alternating Investigation and Trial sections. Most notable new feature is the Psyche Lock - presenting evidence to witnesses in the investigation phase, to uncover the secrets they are hiding.

69356.description:
On the tropical island of Kalua, five religions compete to become the one and only. You will take the role of one of the five Gods that the Kaluans follow and will reward your followers with good harvests, nice weather and general well-being – or, if they don't pray to you enough, punish them with famine, epidemics, floods, earthquakes and other disasters. Don't forget though that with four other Gods on the island, the Kaluans can't distinguish where all their bad luck is coming from...

Make your religion the one and only by converting followers from other religions to your own. The game of Kalua continues until this condition is met.
69356.name: Kalua

69357.name: Jungle Alchemy
rpgsetting: Neiyar: Land of Heaven and the Abyss
69357.description:
From the publisher:

In the world of Neiyar: Land of Heaven and the Abyss, alchemy and science are almost one in the same. Instead of being the domain of spellcasters alone, alchemy is studied by those otherwise shut out from the magical arts. These men and women seek to replicate the effects of magic in order to bring their benefits to the most people... and perhaps take back some of the power the Devi hold over the people.

Jungle Alchemy takes a new look at the craft by looking to the real world for inspiration. Pulling from both modern uses of various plants and their traditional uses of those indigenous to jungle environments. This product includes information on over two dozen real world jungle plants and their traditional uses, as well as additional fantasy plants from the Neiyar campaign setting. Also includes over 50 original alchemy recipes, as well as variants of the core alchemy recipes and recipes from the Neiyar campaign setting. Build batteries, portable ovens, and frost boxes. Brew heart serums and have a chance to bring fallen comrades back to life without divine healing. Give magical potions a special kick with Sorcerer's Brandy. Learn how to craft armor and weapons from sulfuric clay and sulfuric glass. Find advanced rules for poisoncraft, and more!

Though designed for use with the Neiyar campaign setting, Jungle Alchemy can easily fit into any jungle or rainforest campaign.

69358.name: Inns of Harn
69358.description:
Five inns from around the island of Harn are described. Including services and accommodations as well as menu, staff and services. Floor plans are included as well as adventure seeds.

(from back of book)

69359.name: Dragon Lines
69359.description:
From the back of the book:

A Martial Artist's power comes from life-giving Chi, which suffuses the land of the Dragon Empire. It is your duty to use your martial skills and amazing Chi powers to protect the Forbidden City from the hungry ghosts, hopping vampires and Foreign Devils who murder and steal from the innocent.

* Use an expanded Martial Arts system that is compatible with any Basic Roleplaying game. Characters may employ real-life styles, like boxing or ninjitsu; mystical styles that stem from magic; or design their own styles with the tools provided. There are dozens of styles to choose from, and over one hundred Chi Powers.
* Explore the expansive Dragon Empire, where beauty and culture are marred by corruption and decadence. Due to high concentrations of Chi, magical spirits live alongside mortals. Players can choose to be humans, spirits, or something in between.
* Reap the rewards of piety: you might become Enlightened, find a position within the Celestial Bureaucracy, or even take a sip from the Elixir of Immortality.

Dragon Lines is a game of high flying action. Characters can wade through hordes of Lesser Foes, and then duel with another Martial Arts masters. You can survive dangers which would slay ordinary mortals. Walk on water, run up walls and along rooftops, and harness the very powers of Heaven to shoot lightning from your fingertips!

For the Basic Roleplaying system.

69362.name: Epic Dice Battles: Japanese Warfare
69362.description:
EDB: Japanese Warfare was submitted for the "Dicefest Contest - A Tribute to Chessex" held in 2010.

It uses 36 dice in each players color to represent armies, units, actions, and rice production by each player.
Tokens are added to the game to enable hidden unit assignments to the armies, as well as an amount of castles and resources.

Set in feudal Japan, in the end of the Muromachi Period (1136 till 1568 A.D.) before firearms ever made it to the islands, the battles will be conducted between unit of archers, cavalry and Samurai.

EDB: Japanese Warfare is supposed to be the first of a series of games, which use a vast number of dice to represent units in battle scenarios and a simple action-point system to build and strengthen ones armies.

69363.name: Chess³
69363.description:
"An environmental sculpture in chrome steel and crystal clear polished playing boards which moves chess into an intriguing new dimension." (side of box Description)

This game is a relatively straightforward 3-Dimensional extrapolation of the standard chess concept, and as such the goal and theme are much the same, with one player each starting one the top and bottom boards.

Some of the moves for various pieces have been changed, with all pieces moving as per usual on one plane, but the movements from plane to plane of the Queen, Bishop, and Pawn are not as one would initially expect. Most other 3D moves are restricted to moving one square only directly above or below the initial position of the piece.

Board and set could also be used for several other Three Dimensional Chess Variants, as there are no original pieces.

69364.name: Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney: Trials and Tribulations
videogamehonor: 2003 Japan Game Awards Best Unreleased Game Winner
2004 Japan Game Awards Game of the Year Winner
videogamecompilation: Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy HD
69364.description:
User description:

The third game in the Ace Attorney series, and the last one featuring Phoenix Wright as the main character. Originally released in Japan only for the Gameboy Advance platform, and later re-released for Nintendo DS in Japan, Europe, and US. In 2010 the game was ported to WiiWare.

The plot of this game is a continuation of Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney and Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney: Justice for All, and features characters from the first two games in the series. Trials and Tribulations features four new cases for the player to solve.

The gameplay is very similar to previous games, with alternating Investigation and Trial sections.

69365.name: Hotel Dusk: Room 215
videogameversion: North American Nintendo DS (Touch Generations) edition
69365.description:
User description:

The player is Kyle Hyde - an ex-cop, searching for his old partner Brian Bradley. He arrives at Hotel Dusk, a small hotel located near LA. By exploring the hotel, conversing with the hotel guests and interacting with the environment, Kyle gradually uncovers the mysteries surrounding the hotel and its patrons.

One of the most distinctive features of Hotel Dusk: Room 215 are the character graphics - hand-drawn, black & white sketches of people.

69366.name: Golden Age Starships Compilation 1-5
69366.description:
Publisher Blurb:

Compiling the Golden Age Starships, this book features new ships for Traveller, including deck plans, crews, variants and scenario ideas for each. All ships can be found in the official Spinward Marches setting, and the Compilation features the Fast Courier, Corsair, LSP Modular Starship, Sword Worlds Patrol Cruiser, and a collection of archaic small craft and stations for worlds who are just finding their way into space.

Golden Age Starships 1: Fast Courier
Details the 200-ton Fast Courier, a Jump-3 ship originally designed for the Imperial Interstellar Scout Service but now used throughout the Imperium. Some are in private hands, used for movement of high priority and secure cargos and on subsidized routes. This is an ideal ship for characters wanting a vessel a little different from the norm. Full Traveller statistics are provided as well as deckplans, a registry of Fast Couriers in the Spinward Marches, and 7 adventure seeds for merchant campaigns set in the Marches using the Fast Courier. The vessel is designed for player use as well as a ship that players may encounter. It is usually seen carrying mail or priority, secure and hazardous cargos. In addition, details are given on the exploration version of the Fast Courier used by the Imperial Scout Service.

Golden Age Starships 2: Corsair
Contains complete information and deckplans for an upgraded variant of the 400 ton Corsair, known as the Buccaneer class. This corsair class is suitable as a ship that could be encountered by characters if they are travelling anywhere on the fringes of the Imperium and beyond, although the five specific encounters listed in this book are located in the Spinward Marches. Alternatively, this design could be used as the basis of a corsair campaign, with the players taking roles as pirates. Any of the scenarios presented in this book could be used as the basis for a corsair campaign.

Golden Age Starships 3: LSP Modular Starship
Details an entirely new class of ship; a 300 ton "framework" vessel which utilises the versatility cutter modules to create an infinitely customizable vessel. The modular starship can be configured as a cargo hauler, a research vessel, a hospital ship, an escort carrier or whatever else the owners may need. 2 cutter modules are detailed, complete with stats and deckplans for each module, as well as stats for the 600 ton Zhodani patrol corvette and Zhodani 10 ton light fighter, as well as the Imperial 20 ton multi-role fighter, which is carried in one of the cutter modules. Three adventure seeds are also included.

Golden Age Starships 4: Sword Worlds Patrol Cruiser
Outlines the standard, heavily armoured 600-ton Sword Worlds Patrol Cruiser, with complete Mongoose Traveller stats, deckplans, history, variants and operational details. This supplement also contains a short adventure (Amber Zone) set in the Sword Worlds of the Spinward Marches. The adventure comes complete with all NPC stats in Mongoose Traveller format.

Golden Age Starships 5: Archaic Small Craft and Space Stations
Many worlds are Tech Level 6-8, and these worlds may not have access to high tech space travel - this supplement fills the gap by outlining Tech Level 6-8 expansions to the High Guard Small Craft Design Sequence, including rules for reaction-drive launch vehicles (rockets), smaller hulls down to 2.5 dtons and a new drive for the small craft drives table. 23 new designs in the book include launch vehicles, 2 and 3 man archaic small craft from 2.5 to 7.5 dtons, a 20 ton modular launch, 5 ton stratospheric mini-fighter at TL7 and 8+, and 10 ton modules for both the modular launch and to create low-mid tech modular space stations. Many space station designs are also included, ranging from small science stations to defense stations and small highports. Includes a Mercenary Ticket/Amber Zone: Assault On Space Station Alpha, which details an Ine Givar hostage situation on a large modular space station that a military team must solve - by deadly force if necessary.

69367.name: Earthdawn Shards Collection: Volume One
69367.description:
Publisher Blurb:

JOURNEY TO LANG An errand along the Serpent River exposes the characters to the dangers of the Scourge. RUNVIR'S TOMB Searching a tomb for magical treasure, the heroes find that not everything evil is dead. KEPT IN THE DARK In the depths of the Servos Jungle, an expedition takes a different direction when the heroes encounter the Therans. PALE RIVER Beneath the Kingdom of Throal, an underground village harbors thieves. But why are they stealing food from the bazaars of the dwarf city? TOURNAMENT TROUBLES The heroes take part in the annual tournament of Travar, the outcome of which determines the city's political fate for the coming year. Shards Collection Volume One is a collection of five stand-alone adventures for Earthdawn Third Edition, providing challenges for Novice through Journeyman adepts. Requires use of the Earthdawn Player's and Gamemaster's Guides.

69369.name: Bobby and Betty's Trip to the New York World's Fair
69369.description: A souvenir of the 1939 world fair. The board reveals a miniature representation of the futuristic fair. So players could enjoy the various New York attractions in the comfort of their homes.

69370.name: Snap Action Baseball
69370.description:
The thrill and action of real baseball! This tabletop baseball game has a "Snap-action" pitching mound that holds six balls and lets players control the speed of the pitch.
The "Snap-action" bat lets players control the power of the swing. Players hit the ball into the base hit pockets or go for a home run. The game includes scoring dials to record the score as the game progresses.

Changes your tabletop into a baseball stadium.

69371.name: Antagonist
69371.description:
War has come to the ninth century as rival lords (the players) fight to conquer the land. Each player rules a fortress and the surrounding realm. Warriors are dispatched fortress and towers, crossing mountains, rivers, and open fields to engage the enemy. Using economics, diplomacy, and warfare, each player attempts to expand his realm and conquer all enemy fortresses.


Players create a unique geography before each game begins, so it's never the same game twice.
Antagonist is a BIG table game with marauding warriors, changing seasons, burning villages, and limitless strategies.
Straight-forward, intuitive rules with have you playing in minutes.


(From the games label)

69372.name: Battle Royale
69372.description:
War has come to the ninth century as rival lords (the players) fight to conquer the land. Each player rules a fortress and the surrounding realm. Warriors are dispatched fortress and towers, crossing mountains, rivers, and open fields to engage the enemy. Using economics, diplomacy, and warfare, each player attempts to expand his realm and conquer all enemy fortresses.


Players create a unique geography before each game begins, so it's never the same game twice.
Battle Royale is a 2-player version of Antagonist with marauding warriors, changing seasons, burning villages, and limitless strategies.
Straight-forward, intuitive rules with have you playing in minutes.


(From the games label)

69375.name: The Personality Game
69375.description: In The Personality Game one player askes a multiple choice question to a random player. The player asking the question gets a point for correctly predicting what that player will say about themselves. The answering player's playing piece will point in a certain direction based on his answer. That direction leads to one of four different quadrants on a board representing a personality type. At the end of the game, the place where a player's peice ends up indicates their personality. There are also places on the board where players get stuck unless they can get other players to guess a word on a card from that personality type. The stuck player lists examples of the word, without saying the word itself. If they match, they can move on. Other players gain points for matching that word. The first player to score 6 points wins.

69376.name: Faction Guide
69376.description:
From the back of the book:

Loyalty over all

Every campaign has organizations that pull the secret strings of the world, toppling monarchs or leading revolutionaries toward freedom and war. These secret societies, bardic colleges, wizard academies, military orders, and religious cults capture the imagination—and now your PCs can join Golarion’s own movers and shakers with the Pathfinder Chronicles Faction Guide. This book presents a new and detailed rules system for PCs who throw in their lot with one or more of these groups, as well as the responsibilities—and rewards—that membership entails. With membership in a faction, PCs gain a whole new reason to adventure, as well as countless roleplaying opportunities in any sort of campaign, from dungeon crawl to courtly intrigue.

In addition to new goals and motives, membership in a faction comes with tangible in-game benefits. Gain enough of a reputation with the Hellknights, and a PC can become a fearsome lictor, complete with Hellknight minions. Gain prestige with the Pathfinder Society, and a PC adventurer can get his foot in the door to become a venture-captain. Everything your players need to infiltrate the halls of power is right here. Inside this book, you’ll find:


Rules on how to gain prestige with various factions and how to use it to secure items, boons, and allies.
Twenty-four sample factions and the specific benefits of joining them—these factions include the fearsome Red Mantis assassins, the notorious Whispering Way, the righteous Eagle Knights of Andoran, the demon-hunting Mendev Crusaders, the calculating Prophets of Kalistrade, and the blasphemous Church of Razmir.
Standard rewards available through every faction, such as helpful spells, expert hirelings, and access to specific magic items and equipment.
New feats, spells, magic items, and traits for all factions.


This book is intended for use with the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game and the Pathfinder Chronicles campaign setting but fits easily into any fantasy game world.

69377.description: From the back of the box: How do you play Going Ape? By roiling the dice and collecting fruits. Different for beginners and seasoned players, beginning players collect the same fruits but seasoned players collect every fruit. The one who collects the most fruit wins and gets a monkey in reward. The one who has the most monkeys at the end gets the main prize.
69377.name: Apaspil

69379.description:
Who will be first to Legoland? Go on an adventure through four different Lego Worlds as you make your way to Legoland! On every turn players use the remote control to complete on of six different types of activities on the DVD. You'll compete to win a Car Race Navigate a Maze, Shoot a Catapult, Spot the Difference, Play Hot Potato, or figure out the More or Less Lego's Challenge. Every time an activity is mastered the DVD instructs players how to move on the board. But watch out, it may tell players to move backward or switch places. The first player to reach Legoland wins! Game contains interactive DVD, game board, 6 Lego brick playing pieces, and instructions. For 2-6 players ages 6 and up.

--Back of Box
69379.name: LEGO World Explorer DVD Game

69380.name: Spilmagasinet Ravnen (Issue 5 - Winter 1993)
69380.description:
Index:
1 Forside (Front page - René K. Larsen)
2 Credits
3 Leders in the Night (Editorial - Bo Jørgensen)
4 Vampyrens Oprindelse (Origin of the Vampire)
6 Dracula (Film review - Rune L. Christensen)
10 Danser med varulve (Dances with werewolves - Søren)
13 Betal kontingent eller dø (Pay contingent or die - Kasseren)
14 HekseHetz (WitchPersecution)
15 Skatkisten (Treasure chest)
16 Vampire Quotes
18 Julearrangement '92 (X-mas con '92 - Flemming Sander Jensen)
21 Vampire Chronicles (Review - Kim Petersen)
24 I Smeltediglen (pre-view of Infinite Nexus, a new RPG - Michael E. Næsby)
26 En grusom mistanke (review of Cruel Doubt by Joe McGinniss - Kim Petersen)
27 Eventyr for åben skærm (Computer adventures - Thomas Sørensen)
28 Kassen (Letters - Hans B. Petersen)
30 Wutz going on?!! (Game news)
31 (Rene K. Larsen)
32 Bagside (Rear page)

69381.name: Daisessen Zenya
69381.description:
User summary:

A fantasy platform adventure game featuring the anime character Ayu.

Translated box back:
The girls met in the saddest of all dreams in the world
They opened the lid of catastrophy
They cried for eternity, unable to go home.
Because they wanted another one to smile.

–This is the beginning of a nightmare fwom which you will never awake–

69382.name: Lethal Application
69382.description:
User Summary:

A platform game where the player uses the recoil of the gun to fly upwards. The goal of each stage is on the top.

Translated box back:
Note: This is a vertical scroll platform/shooting game in which you use the recoil to fly. I believe it's best if you don't expect any bullet hell.

The weapon uses the gun recoil to soar in the sky.

A unique flying experience.
Use the four special weapons to defeat all your foes!
Use the Burst Mode to save yourself from danger ang gain high scores!
10 stages, 6 bosses and a secret!

69383.name: They Say That Once Upon a Time There Was a Land in Which Lived Two Twin-Tailed Sister Princesses Who Really Hated Each Other
69383.description:
User summary:

A platform game based on the idea from "Dokidoki panic" (the game that was remade into Super Mario Bros 2 in the US), where you pull stuff out from the ground and throw it at your foes.

Translated box back:
This was a fight among sisters, so vast that it threatened the entire country…
Pull the enemies, the twin tails, and everything you don't know what it is, out of the ground and throw it!
The one who abandons common sense will win. This is the root-pulling platform action game!

69384.name: The Royal Edma Engine
69384.description:
User summary:

A bullet hell shooter in isometric 3D (so-called quarter view), where the point of view is from the top side. The played is advancing diagonally into the screen.

Translated box back:

A bullet hell shooter in a new perspective!!!
Her head's really in the way, but don't mind the details!!!
Sushi tastes great!!!

69385.name: Maid to the Right
69385.description:
User summary:

A home-made (home-maid?) platform game in Castlevania-style, featuring a maid. The player must avoid and kill enemies, pick up keys and open doors,all the while reaching the exit before the time runs out.

The voice effects, especially the one when the maid is killed, quickly became a semi-cult in the Japanese fandom world for indie games. The game itself, is like most Platine games, disturbingly hard.

Translated box back:
Dear maid
Dear Maid
Aa, dear maid

"Naaaw! I'm dying!"
"Buwah!"
"Are you killing me?"
"Buwah!"

Please… please… don't die so easily

69386.name: GundeadliGne
69386.description:
User summary:

A horisontal bullet hell shooter, where you can chande the direction of your character's shots.

Translated box back:
WELCOME TO HELL!!!!

The portal to the maze of bullets has broken, so hell is let loose!
With a careful use of the Plane Shift system from the Matrix Masters, I believe even you can survive in this world!
Come, it's time for a bungie jump without safety line into an unexplored world of bullet mazes!

69387.name: Hitogatahappa
69387.description:
User summary:

A bullet hell where the point isn't only to avoid, but to kamikaze-crash into the enemies for maximum damage.

Translated box back:

To defeat the all-purpose technology, The doll wars, Summer Tea party is started by two lone warriors.

Gundemonium episode #0

69388.name: Lone Wolf Club Newsletter (Issue 13 - 1989)
69388.description:
User summary of articles in this newsletter:

Monastery Mailbag: a selection of letters from Lone Wolf fans.
Two missing pages in Internet Edition version from Project Aon.
Kai Story Competition: a winner of a previous newsletter's competition.
The Kai Konnection: a pen-friend listing feature.
Why G.M.?: an advertisement for G.M. magazine.
Eclipse of the Kai: the second part of a serialisation of the Legends of Lone Wolf novels by Joe Dever and John Grant.
Order Form: for purchasing Lone Wolf Gamebooks, Combat Heroes, and Freeway Warrior (Gamebook) gamebooks.
Priority Order Form: an offer to purchase Slaughter Mountain Run signed by the author.
News from the Monastery: previewing various new releases.
2-Part Word Search Competition: requiring entrants to find thirty countries of Magnamund given a list of their capital cities.

69389.name: Chelsea Must Kick the Living Daylights Out of Seven Bosses
69389.description:
User summary:
A Japanese home-made crazy platform action game for Windows2K and up.

Translated box back:

An action game using time in a wonderland!
Search the exciting mazes together with the cursed rabbit!

69390.name: Lone Wolf Club Newsletter (Issue 14 - 1989)
69390.description:
User summary of articles in this newsletter:

News from the Monastery: previewing various new releases.
Kai Story Competition: a winner of a previous newsletter's competition.
The Kai Konnection: a pen-friend listing feature.
Lone Wolf Grand Master Adventure: previewing the rules (in particular the Disciplines) for the Grand Master series.
Two missing pages in Internet Edition version from Project Aon.
Competition Results: solution to and winners of a previous newsletter's Kai Grand Master competition.
Draw a Monster Competition: requiring entrants to illustrate an enemy of Lone Wolf using the feet and sword blade provided as the basis.

69391.name: Shades of Terror
69391.description:
Site blurb at Dragonsfoot:
A "Call of Cthulhu" type adventure but powered by Savage Worlds. Be warned, this adventure is not suitable for young players..

69392.name: Lone Wolf Club Newsletter (Issue 15 - 1989)
69392.description:
User summary of articles in this newsletter:

Lone Wolf Gamebook Series Review: results of user reviews of the first twelve books in the series.
Priority Order Form: an offer to purchase California Countrdown signed by the author.
Joe Dever's PhoneQuest: a detailed account of The Fortress of Doom, a telephone adventure game based on Book 07: Castle Death.
The Kai Konnection: a pen-friend listing feature.
Lone Wolf RPG - An Outline: a basic role-playing system based on the world of Lone Wolf.
Competition Results: solution to and winners of a previous newsletter's word search competition.
Priority Order Form: an offer to purchase The Sword of the Sun (book 3 of the Legends of Lone Wolf series, based on Book 02: Fire on the Water) signed by the author.
Order Form: for purchasing Lone Wolf Gamebooks, Combat Heroes, and Freeway Warrior (Gamebook) gamebooks.
Captain Khadro's Lone Wolf Treasure Competition: requiring entrants to use their knowledge of Magnamund to find the location of the treasure.

69393.name: Lone Wolf Club Newsletter (Issue 16 - 1990)
69393.description:
User summary of articles in this newsletter:

News from the Monastery: previewing various new releases.
Book 13: The Plague Lords of Ruel: the introductory story from the gamebook.
Priority Order Form: an offer to purchase Hunting Wolf (book 4 of the Legends of Lone Wolf series, based on Book 03: The Caverns of Kalte) signed by the author.
The Kai Konnection: a pen-friend listing feature.
The Fifth British Play by Mail Convention: an advertisement for the event.
Order Form: for purchasing Lone Wolf Gamebooks, Combat Heroes, and Freeway Warrior (Gamebook) gamebooks.
Competition Results: winners of a previous newsletter's Draw a Monster competition, and solution to and winners of the previous newsletter's Treasure Hunt competition.
Banedon's Quest: a Lone Wolf Treasure Hunt Competition: requiring entrants to use their knowledge of Magnamund to find the location of Nadazgada, the sword of Darklord Gnaag.

69394.name: Eternal Fighter Zero
videogameexpansion: Eternal Fighter Zero Bad Moon edition
Eternal Fighter Zero Blue Sky edition
69394.description:
User summary:

Twilight Frontier's first famous fighter game, feature anime characters from Leaf and Key works.

The game got two extra character discs: EFZ Blue Sky edition and FÉFZ Bad Moon edition. They were all stuffed together into the Eternal Fighter Zero Memorial edition, on one DVD rom.

69395.name: Lone Wolf Club Newsletter (Issue 17 - 1990)
69395.description:
User summary of articles in this newsletter:

News from the Monastery: previewing various new releases.
Joe Dever's PhoneQuest: an advertisement for the games Alien Intruder, Ninja, The Forbidden Tower (a Lone Wolf adventure), Tomb of the Sphinx, and Vampire Hunter.
The Adventures of Sabre Fox, Firefly, Black Hawk & Wild Weasel: part one of a fan-written story set in Magnamund.
The Kai Konnection: a pen-friend listing feature.
Congratulations Morgan!: the news story of a member of the Lone Wolf Club that has won the Raintree Publishers' 1990 "Publish-a-Book" contest.
GamesMaster International: an advertisement for the newly rebranded gaming magazine.
Competition Results: solution to and winners of the previous newsletter's Treasure Hunt competition.
Priority Order Form: an offer to purchase Book 13: The Plague Lords of Ruel signed by the author.
Kai Grand Master Master Quiz: requiring entrants to use their copies of the gamebooks to find the answers.

69396.name: Eternal Fighter Zero Bad Moon edition
69396.description:
User summary:

Extra characters for Eternal Fighter Zero.

69397.name: Eternal Fighter Zero Blue Sky edition
69397.description:
User summary:

Extra characters for Eternal Fighter Zero

69398.name: Lone Wolf Club Newsletter (Issue 18 - 1991)
69398.description:
User summary of articles in this newsletter:

The Adventures of Sabre Fox, Firefly, Black Hawk & Wild Weasel: part two of a fan-written story set in Magnamund.
The Kai Konnection: a pen-friend listing feature.
The Lean Cow: a short story by Joe Dever set in England in the time of King Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table and inspired by a verse which appears in the English literary medieval classic Canterbury Tales by Geoffrey Chaucer. It tells the story of an unusual quest, reluctantly undertaken by Sir Mordred of Orkney, the notorious 'black sheep' of King Arthur's court.
The Sixth British Play by Mail Convention: an advertisement for the event.
Order Form: for purchasing Lone Wolf Gamebooks and Freeway Warrior (Gamebook) gamebooks.
News from the Monastery: previewing various new releases.
Priority Order Form: an offer to purchase Book 14: The Captives of Kaag signed by the author.
Book 13: The Plague Lords of Ruel Competition: requiring entrants to use their copy of the gamebook to find the answers.

69399.description:
From the publisher:

"Space Frontier is a card game of space exploration. Can you colonize more planets with sufficient resources than the Invader fleet?

Choose from several different space ships to create your exploration fleet. Each ship has a different ability that is activated by discovering a planet with a specific resource type.

Once two systems have been fully explored (or the Invaders have explored one system), the game ends, and you add up the scores. If your point value is higher than the Invader's points, you win.

A variety of Invader ships let you adjust the difficulty of play, and advanced rules allow you to challenge yourself even further.

Space Frontier can be played solitaire, or with two players (head-to-head or cooperatively)."
69399.name: Space Frontier

69400.name: BlazBlue: Calamity Trigger
videogamehonor: 2009 Spike Best Fighting Game of the Year Nominee
69400.description: BlazBlue is a traditional, technical, 2D fighting game with a Science Fiction / Anime theme set in a world where Magic and Technology co-exist.

69401.name: Lost Odyssey
69401.description:
Lost Odyssey is set in a world in which a "Magic-Industrial Revolution" is taking place. While magic energy existed in all living creatures beforehand, it suddenly became far more powerful thirty years before the beginning of the game. Because of this, it has affected society greatly, with devices called "Magic Engines" harnessing this power for lighting, automobiles, communication, and robots, among other uses. While previously only a select few could wield magic, many magicians gained the ability. However, such progress has also caused two nations; the kingdom of Gohtza, and the Republic of Uhra, recently changed from a monarchical society; to develop new and more powerful weapons of mass destruction. Uhra is building Grand Staff, a gigantic magic engine, while the heavily industrialized Gohtza actively pursued magic research of their own. A third nation, the Free Ocean State of Numara, has remained isolated and neutral, though it is falling into disarray due to a general attempting to stage a coup d'etat. Uhra, at war with Khent, a nation of beastmen, sends its forces to the Highlands of Wohl for a decisive battle at the start of the game.

Source: Wikipedia, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lost_Odyssey,"; available under the CC-BY-SA License.

69402.name: Chime
69402.description:
Chime is a block-dropping game that combines elements from both Lumines and Tetris. Players control a single shape at a time, and can move, rotate, and then place it onto a grid. A beatline moves across the grid in time with the music, setting off events when it hits placed shapes. Quads are created by placing shapes in solid blocks of 3x3 or more. When a quad is completed and the beat line hits, different musical samples are triggered dependent on its shape. The size of the quad denotes the score, and multipliers can be achieved by having several quads on the screen at once. Once the beatline hits a completed quad, it is stamped down into the grid, earning the player coverage. The overall objective is to achieve 100% coverage to earn more time and score points.

Source: Wikipedia, "Chime (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

69403.name: Castle Crashers
videogamehonor: 2007 IGF Awards Audience Choice Winner
2007 IGF Awards Excellence In Visual Art Winner
2009 D.I.C.E. Best Animation of the Year Nominee
2009 Game Developers Choice Awards Best Downloadable Game of the Year Nominee
69403.description:
From Wikipedia:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Castle_Crashers

Castle Crashers is a side-scrolling, beat-em-up which incorporates a small number of role-playing game elements. - After selecting a character, the player then selects a starting level (beginning with the wizard's attack on the castle) through a graph-like world map; once the player completes a level, they may then opt to start or revisit that level any time. Other levels include shops where the player can buy items for healing, attacking, or defense using coins gained from defeated foes, and arena levels where the player can take on challenges to unlock additional characters, although in co-op the arena turns into a player vs player match. This goes for the same as when the players defeat the boss, freeing the princess, and if there are two or more, the battle starts to see who gets the princess' kiss. - In each level, the player can use a number of melee attacks and combination attacks in addition to a unique magical ability each character has in order to defeat foes. The player has a health meter that, if drained from enemy attacks, will cause the character to fall in battle; if the player is playing alone, this ends the level and the player will have to start it over; otherwise, any of the other players may attempt to revive the downed character. The player's magic level is also tracked by a meter and regenerates over time. Numerous weapons can be found in the game, each that have various effects to the character's attributes when equipped. There are also animal orbs that can be found that may help out in battle, improve the character's attributes, or provide another special ability such as gaining more treasure from defeated foes. After a player damages an enemy, they gain experience points, eventually gaining the player a new level. Each level gained allows the player to allocate points towards four basic attributes to improve that character in combat. One character can "level up" to level 99 which is accomplished by amassing exactly 113,680 exp points. Certain level advances also grant new combination attacks. Progress in experience and game completion is tracked for each of the playable characters separately. New playable characters can be earned by completing the game with a new character, or through downloadable characters from Xbox Live Marketplace, such as the titular character from Alien Hominid.

69404.name: Mass Effect: Bring Down the Sky
69404.description:
"The first piece of downloadable content (known as DLC) was announced on February 6, 2008. The Bring Down The Sky pack was released on March 10, 2008 for the Xbox 360 as a paid download and on July 29, 2008 for Windows as a free download. It should also be noted that as of late January 2009, the DLC was made compatible with the Steam version, titled revision a. As with retail box copies, players will need to register their Steam serial number on BioWare's website in order to receive the serial number required for installing the DLC.

Bring Down the Sky includes a new uncharted world that introduces the notorious and feared batarians, a humanoid species with four eyes. A batarian extremist group has hijacked a mobile asteroid station in the Asgard system, setting it on a collision course with the nearby colony world of Terra Nova. Only Commander Shepard can save the millions of innocent civilians before the asteroid completes its deadly descent. This mission is concurrent with the main storyline. BioWare has stated that the adventure should take ninety minutes to complete. The expansion also features an additional achievement awarded upon completion of the mission titled as "Colonial Savior" with a value of 50 points. Additionally, in the PC version of the game, a message may be found in a small music outpost on the asteroid when the computer inside is read twice. The message appears to be a humorous jab by the developers at those who stirred up the controversies surrounding the game's romance scenes upon its initial release."

Source: Wikipedia, "Mass_Effect," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

69405.name: Scribblenauts
videogamehonor: 2009 Game Critics Best Handheld Game of the Year Winner
2009 Game Critics Best Social/Casual/Puzzle Game of the Year Nominee
2009 Game Critics Most Original Game of the Year Winner
2009 Gamescom Best Mobile/Handheld Game of the Year Nominee
2009 Spike Best Handheld/Mobile Game of the Year Nominee
2010 British Academy Game Awards Best Handheld/Mobile Game of the Year Nominee
2010 D.I.C.E. Best Casual Game of the Year Nominee
2010 D.I.C.E. Best Handheld Game of the Year Winner
2010 D.I.C.E. Best Innovation of the Year Winner
2010 Game Developers Choice Awards Best Handheld/Mobile Game of the Year Winner
2010 Game Developers Choice Awards Best Innovation of the Year Winner
2011 Japan Game Awards Most Innovative Game Winner
69405.description:
A unique puzzle game where you create objects needed to solve puzzles by typing in their names. For example - when you need to cut down a tree, you can invoke an axe for your character, but a chainsaw, TNT, beaver, or lumberjack would all do the trick.

There are two game modes: Puzzle and Action, and both use the same mechanic of invoking objects. In Puzzle mode the objective is different in each stage, while in Action mode the goal is to find and obtain a Starite item located somewhere in the stage.

69409.name: Soldat II
69409.description:
Soldat is a set of rules for simulating squad level infantry combat during the early and mid Twentieth Century. The rules concentrate on the World Wars, but can also be used for Korea, Indochina and the early Arab-Israeli wars.
Unlike the great majority of wargame rules for this period, Soldat concentrates on the role of the infantryman. Combat in both World Wars rapidly became a series of vicious, small unit actions, a classic confrontation at close quarters with no holds barred. As in most wars, the dirty business of winning battles fell to the infantryman. Despite the vast array of sophisticated and deadly weapons available to all sides, success or failure ultimately depended upon the ability of the foot soldier to take or hold ground.

http://smpartizans.com/index.html

http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/SMPress/

69410.name: Kewbz
69410.description:
From the publisher's website:

In the clever, creative, competitive, and captivating game of Kewbz™, opposing players compete for ownership of 'tower units' by positioning the final cube on top. Each time a corner is made, a cube is stacked at the intersection. When multiple corners are created, then multiple cubes are added into play. Clever strategy moves give you the winning edge.

69412.name: Klirr
69412.description:
A card game with gaming money. Bluff the value of the cards to gain a million.

The Players randomly draw cards containing different values. they then declare the value of the card, either the real value or bluffing. If the claim is not challenged by any other player, the active player received the amount of money he declared from the bank.
If it is challenged (called) and the player was bluffing, he needs to pay the double amount declared to the calling player. If he was not bluffing the calling player needs to pay the double amount to the active player.
The player with most money when all the cards have been played wins.

69413.name: ROLLette
69413.description:
From the box: Ready, set, ROLL! Land three or more marbles in a row and score!

Object: Be the first player to score 50 points. Score points by landing your marbles to create rows of three or more in the same quadrant.

User comment: The game consist of 25 marbles (5 each of 5 colors) and a circular board, about 12 inches in diameter. Around the outer rim of the board are 28 three-quarter inch holes. Between the holes and the rim of the board is where a player will roll his marble--in the style of a roulette wheel--and hope it lands in a desirable hole in a desirable quadrant of the board. Landing several marbles in a row gains points, whether they be three in a row of your color or of mixed colors.

Instructions are printed on the bottom of the box.

69415.name: Family Computer Disk System
69415.description:
The Family Computer Disk System (ファミリーコンピュータ ディスクシステム, sometimes abbreviated as the Famicom Disk System, the Disk System, or simply the FDS) was released on February 21, 1986 by Nintendo as a peripheral for the Family Computer ("Famicom") console in Japan. It was a unit that used proprietary floppy disks (called "disk cards") for data storage. It was announced, but never released, for the North American Nintendo Entertainment System. Through its entire production span, 1986-2003, 4.5 million units were sold.

The device was connected to the Famicom deck by plugging a modified cartridge known as the RAM Adapter into the system's cartridge port, which attached via a supplied cable to the disk drive. The RAM adapter contained 32 kilobytes of RAM for temporary program storage, 8 kilobytes of RAM for tile and sprite data storage, and an ASIC known as the 2C33. The ASIC acted as a disk controller for the floppy drive, and also included additional sound hardware featuring primitive wavetable synthesis and FM synthesis capabilities. The disk cards used were double-sided, with a total capacity of 896 kilobits or 112 kilobytes per disk. Many games spanned both sides of a disk, requiring the user to switch sides at some point during gameplay. A few games used two full disks (four sides). The Disk System was capable of running on six C-cell batteries or the supplied AC adapter. Batteries would usually last 5 months on daily game play. The battery option was included due to the likelihood of a standard set of AC plugs already being occupied by a Famicom and a television.

Source: Wikipedia, "Family Computer Disk System", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

videogamefranchise: Player's Choice (Best Selling Nintendo Games, US & EU)
videogamecompilation: The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past / Four Swords
videogame: The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past / Four Swords
69417.description:
The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past, known in Japan as Zeruda no Densetsu: Kamigami No Toraifōsu (ゼルダの伝説 神々のトライフォース, lit. "The Legend of Zelda: Triforce of the Gods"), is an action-adventure video game developed and published by Nintendo for the Super Nintendo Entertainment System video game console, and the third installment in The Legend of Zelda series. It was first released in Japan in 1991, and was later released in North America and Europe in 1992. Shigeru Miyamoto and his team were solely responsible for this game's development.

A Link to the Past's plot focuses on Link as he travels on a journey to save Hyrule, defeat Ganon and rescue the seven descendants of the Sages. A Link to the Past uses a top-down perspective similar to that of the original The Legend of Zelda. It added mechanics and concepts to the series that have become commonplace, including multi-level dungeons and new equipment (such as the hookshot and the Pegasus Boots), as well as establishing the concept of an alternate, parallel (and sometimes far more dangerous) world. It was well-received since its release, and has been listed by GameSpot as one of the best installments of the series, as well as one of the greatest games of all time. To date, A Link to the Past has sold more than four million copies, and has been re-released for the Game Boy Advance and the Wii's Virtual Console. The GBA remake was released together with the other Zelda game The 4 swords.

Source: Wikipedia, "The_Legend_of_Zelda:_A_Link_to_the_Past," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Individual credits:
Koji Kondo: Music
videogamehonor: 2003 Golden Joystick Handheld Game of the Year Nominee
69417.name: The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past

69418.name: Shenmue II
69418.description:
User summary:
The second installment in Yu Suzuki's Shenmue series, this game is a direct continuation of the story in the first Shenmue game, and contains chapter 2 to 4.

Despite the immense critical acclaim the first game had received in the west, the sales in Japan were poor and Shenmue II sold very badly in Japan. As the game was slightly more successful in the West, the game was ported to Xbox in Europe and America only.

Translated box back:
Shenmue, to a different region
More than 1000 characters, vast fields, and an impressive world scale to see for yourself.
Contains movies of famous scenes from Shenmue I – fully playable for those who have yet to play Shenmue I.

English box back:

An Epic Quest in a Modern World

Seeking answers and vengeance, Ryo Hazuki arrives in the bustling metropolis of Hong Kong. Encountering new friends and foes alike, Ryo realizes he has much to learn and must master new martial art skills to prepare himself for his ultimate showdown with Lan Di, the man who killed his father. Each day brings Ryo closer to his goal of avenging his father's death and unlocking the mysteries of the Phoenix Mirror.

69419.name: Plus Plumb
69419.description:
User summary:

A typical VS puzzle game with colour-coded blips to match together in order to make them disappear, like Puyo Puyo. The game is played on scales, so the more stuff you have on your half, the heavier it is. You win if the scales tip over to your opponent's side.

69420.name: Pen Pen TRiIceLon
69420.description:
User summary:

A simple triathlon game with a penguin theme. Players race, swim and walk through stages as a standard racing game.

69421.name: Godzilla Generations
69421.description:
User summary:

A generic Godzilla game where you roam around in slow motion toppling the buildings in the towns. You can choose between all the different Godzillas; even the American Godzilla is there.

69422.name: Player's Guide to Glorantha
69422.description:
Publisher Blurb:

In it glorious Second Age, Glorantha is the prize of warring empires. Two empires, more similar that they'd like to admit, vie for ultimate dominance. The God Learner Empire seeks to crack open and the very secrets of the gods, manipulating them to their own ends. The Empire of Wyrm's Friends works to transform its land and people into a gigantic, mystical dragon, which will take flight and reshape the entire world. The Second Age is a time of unprecedented discovery and exploration. For the first time, trade and travel allows the interaction of far-flung cultures. Both Empires innovate feverishly, unveiling new forms of magic, new devices, new modes of perception. Against this backdrop of unfettered progress, dark omens gather. Men have pushed the Glorantha's eternal laws of myth and magic to the breaking point. How long will it be before the world strikes back at them, punishing their unprecedented hubris?

69423.name: ChuChu Rocket!
videogameversion: North American Game Boy Advance edition
videogamehonor: 2001 Game Critics Best Social/Casual/Puzzle Game of the Year Nominee
69423.description:
User summary:

A hysteric multiplayer action game, where the players control one mouse cursor each, and compete for placing arrows on the square-gridded map to guide the ever-flowing mice into their respective rockets. The player with the most mice in his rocket after the time limit wins.

69424.name: Puyo Puyoon
69424.description:
User summary:

In Puyo Puyo 4, the characters went from two head height to 5 had height. The chain system worked as in previous games, but the handicap system worked rather differently; instead of adding more colours for the higher levels, each level meant you needed one more chain reaction to achieve the same result.

The game also contained puzzle modes.

69425.name: GigaWing 2
69425.description:
User summary:

A sequel to Takumi's Gigawing. In this game, you can choose between Reflect Force or Reflect Laser. The former bounces all shots off you, the latter absorbs all shots you get during a couple of seconds, to then release an array of lasers on everything on screen.

The arcade allowed for 2 players simultaneously, but the Dreamcast port had a 4-player mode.

69426.name: Granbretan
69426.description:
From publisher blurb:

For this was the great power of the Lords of the Dark Empire, that they valued nothing on all the Earth, no human quality, nothing within or without themselves. The spreading of conquest and desolation, of terror and torment, was their staple entertainment, a means of employing their hours until their spans of life were ended. For them, warfare was merely the most satisfying way of easing their ennui.

The Dark Empire of Granbretan reaches out to conquer the world! Within his life-sustaining Throne Globe, the immortal King-Emperor Huon raises a withered hand and a million beast-masked warriors charge across the Silver Bridge. They desire to conquer the world, to enslave all humanity so that the mad Granbretanians can indulge in their twisted lusts or depraved hatreds. No army in Europe can stand against the flame-lances and foul sorceries of the Dark Empire. No force in all the world can staunch the wounds they inflict – save for the eldritch influence of the Runestaff!

War is coming. Where will you make your stand against the Dark Empire?

This 128-page book details all the Byzantine depravities of glorious Granbretan. From its decadent nobility to its twisted history and infamous populace, Granbretan is the essential handbook to adventuring in this dark land. Rounding out this Hawkmoon supplement is a brand new adventure, designed to plunge adventurers head-first into the nightmare – Hunters of Granbretan!

An expansion for Hawkmoon the Roleplaying Game.

69427.name: White Illumination
69427.description:
User summary:

A romance adventure set on Hokkaido, and with an impressive amount of local information of shops and cafés, complete with web access if you hook up your Dreamcast.

The game featured a system where, instead of choosing dialogue when it came, you could interrupt the ongoing monologue to add in a comment.
